bugs.bug_description:
Given the following table definition:

CREATE TABLE `chatroom_ban_list` (
  `crid` int(11) NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT,
  `uid` int(11) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
  `admin_uid` int(11) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
  `modified` int(11) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
  KEY `crid_uid` (`crid`,`uid`)
) ENGINE=InnoDB DEFAULT CHARSET=utf8

mysqldump --innodb-optimize-keys will generate the following CREATE TABLE:

CREATE TABLE `chatroom_ban_list` (
  `crid` int(11) NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT,
  `uid` int(11) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
  `admin_uid` int(11) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
  `modified` int(11) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0'
) ENGINE=InnoDB DEFAULT CHARSET=utf8

Which fails with the following error:

ERROR 1075 (42000): Incorrect table definition; there can be only one auto column and it must be defined as a key

Admittedly, the original table designed is flawed, but MySQL accepts it, so --innodb-optimize-keys should probably make sure that compound keys aren't the only keys on auto increment columns before moving them out of the CREATE TABLE statement.
bugs.bug_title: mysqldump --innodb-optimize-keys can generate invalid table definitions

bugs.bug_description:
The TIME column in I_S.PROCESSLIST may be off by 1 second. Consider the following example:

A query starts at the 0.8 sec timestamp, and takes 0.231 sec. The seconds delta in TIME (that is the difference between the current time in seconds and the start time in seconds) will be 1, but the milliseconds one will be 0.231.

The fix is to calculate the delta using a higher resolution timer and then round it correctly to seconds.
bugs.bug_title: Incorrectly rounded TIME value in I_S.PROCESSLIST

Track history for 600 seconds. Only data older than that will be purged.

- Add the trxid to time mapping so we can understand where each trx belongs (optional)

- Add ability to recover to given trx-id on  point in time recovery (all newer transactions will be rolled back)

NOTE: This can be a bit complicated as transactions do not commit in the order they are started.

And I issue the following query:

SELECT `id` FROM `t1` WHERE `c3`=6;

This will show that the index has been used, but what I want to know is how many bytes were used.  This way I can not only drop unused indexes, but also shorten indexes that include too many columns.

bugs.bug_description:
I'd like SHOW INNODB STATUS to show information about the sequence of queries in a transaction.  For example, currently we have this:

> ---TRANSACTION 671D852DC, ACTIVE 129 sec, OS thread id 645706 fetching rows
> mysql tables in use 40, locked 20
> 53464 lock struct(s), heap size 5470192, 581114 row lock(s)
> MySQL thread id 249386396, query id 2074123394 192.168.62.210 user1 preparing

I'd like to see more information, like this:

> ---TRANSACTION 671D852DC, ACTIVE 129 sec, OS thread id 645706 fetching rows
> First query id 2074123390; 2 queries in transaction

This tells me what query ID the transaction started with.  It tells me this is the 2nd in the transaction.  This can be very useful for getting context about a query.  For example, there is a SELECT query with some locks.  Why?  Maybe because an earlier query was an UPDATE.  Or, there is an active transaction that doesn't seem to have any query currently.  Has this transaction ever executed a query?

bugs.bug_description:
For workload analysis, it would be very helpful to have timing data for all of the Com_ counters in SHOW STATUS.

For example, if you see a spike in query time, which types of commands consumed the time?  If a particular type of query is run more frequently, then graphs of the Com_ counters will show that.  But if the query is run the same amount of times but has an unstable query plan and isn't using an index sometimes, the counters will be the same and the response time is what will change.

Another example: has the ratio of time spent executing reads -vs- writes changed?  Or, how much time is spent executing writes?  These answers can be helpful to understand things such as whether the slave is likely to start falling behind soon.  Examining a graph of the sum of the response time of all the write queries can show whether there is more execution time than wall-clock time, which will cause the slave to fall behind.

Here's a sample of current output:

  Com_show_keys
  Com_show_logs
  Com_show_master_status
  Com_show_ndb_status

What I'd like to see is

  Com_show_keys
  Com_show_keys_time

And so forth.  This should be a floating-point number in seconds.  Or, an integer with microseconds elapsed.  Either is fine for me.
bugs.bug_title: Add timing data to all Com_ counters in SHOW STATUS
bugs.title: Bug #589480 in Percona Server: "Add timing data to all Com_ counters in SHOW STATUS"

bugs.bug_description: The Handler API is not fully instrumented.  Critical Handler calls are not counted in SHOW STATUS.  This makes it significantly harder to understand what queries are doing.  The counter I've wished for the most is Handler::statistics(), but I believe the entire API should be instrumented with SHOW STATUS counters.
bugs.bug_title: Instrument more of the Handler API
bugs.title: Bug #589482 in Percona Server: "Instrument more of the Handler API"

bugs.bug_description:
SHOW PROFILES is great, but the most interesting thing is the timing data -- all the un-implemented functionality for other things is not necessary.  I also don't like that it uses getrusage() which is inaccurate (only centisecond-level, and implemented by polling) and too expensive.

I propose an INFORMATION_SCHEMA table with global and session counters for the time spent in each thread status.  It should also count the number of times that status was entered and exited.  This will make it quite obvious when a particular status, such as "Statistics" or "Copying to tmp table," suddenly begins consuming more time than usual, or being entered more than usual.  I propose that you should be able to do the following:

SELECT * FROM INFORMATION_SCHEMA.SESSION_THREAD_STATUS;
SELECT * FROM INFORMATION_SCHEMA.GLOBAL_THREAD_STATUS;

and you'd get something like this:

+-------------------------------+------------+----------+
| Status                        | Count_Star | SUM_Time |
+-------------------------------+------------+----------+
| Statistics                    |          5 |    0.001 | 
| Copying to tmp table          |         11 |    0.238 | 
| Waiting for query cache mutex |       1818 |   58.112 | 
+-------------------------------+------------+----------+

This data would also be extremely good for building Cacti graphs!
bugs.bug_title: Add INFORMATION_SCHEMA table for time spent in different thread statuses

bugs.bug_description:
I'd like the following global variables in SHOW STATUS:

Busy_time is the total wall-clock time during which user threads were executing queries.  This is not the same as Threads_running > 0, because Threads_running is > 0 when there are slaves or event threads executing.

Query_time is the total query time accumulated by the server, including currently executing queries (this is very important).

Uptime_hires is simply a high-resolution Uptime.

The Busy_time is similar to field 10 in /proc/diskstats.  The Query_time is similar to field 11.  See http://www.mjmwired.net/kernel/Documentation/iostats.txt for details on this.  It is worth reading how the numbers are computed in /proc/diskstats.

This information is amazingly powerful for performance analysis.  It lets you do all kinds of things with queueing theory and Little's Law.  It lets you apply Neil Gunther's universal scalability law to predict the scaling limits of the server.  I have gotten the same information from TCP traffic and validated its usefulness.  You can see an 'awk' implementation here: http://aspersa.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/usl Look in the convert_tcpdump_tabulate()  function.

This is related to https://bugs.launchpad.net/tcprstat/+bug/634306 but implementing it inside the server is much more powerful.
bugs.bug_title: Add Busy_time, Query_time, and Uptime_hires
bugs.title: Bug #666597 in Percona Server: "Add Busy_time, Query_time, and Uptime_hires"

Hello,

The MySQL Server Facebook Edition offers many useful fields in table_statistics : 
-  `TABLE_ENGINE` varchar(192) NOT NULL DEFAULT '',
-  `ROWS_INSERTED` bigint(21) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
-  `ROWS_UPDATED` bigint(21) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
-  `ROWS_DELETED` bigint(21) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
-  `ROWS_READ` bigint(21) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
-  `ROWS_REQUESTED` bigint(21) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
-  `IO_READ_BYTES` bigint(21) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
-  `IO_READ_REQUESTS` bigint(21) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
-  `IO_READ_SVC_USECS` bigint(21) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
-  `IO_READ_SVC_USECS_MAX` bigint(21) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
-  `IO_READ_WAIT_USECS` bigint(21) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
-  `IO_READ_WAIT_USECS_MAX` bigint(21) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
-  `IO_READ_OLD_IOS` bigint(21) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
-  `IO_WRITE_BYTES` bigint(21) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
-  `IO_WRITE_REQUESTS` bigint(21) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
-  `IO_WRITE_SVC_USECS` bigint(21) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
-  `IO_WRITE_SVC_USECS_MAX` bigint(21) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
-  `IO_WRITE_WAIT_USECS` bigint(21) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
-  `IO_WRITE_WAIT_USECS_MAX` bigint(21) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
-  `IO_WRITE_OLD_IOS` bigint(21) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
-  `IO_INDEX_INSERTS` bigint(21) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0'

There are also new fields in user_statistics : 
-  `ROWS_DELETED` bigint(21) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
-  `ROWS_INSERTED` bigint(21) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
-  `ROWS_READ` bigint(21) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',

This could be useful to add it in Percona Server.

Related commits in Facebook edition are : (may missed some, I'm not a mysql internals guru) : 
http://bazaar.launchpad.net/~mysqlatfacebook/mysqlatfacebook/5.1/revision/3431

Other revisions you may take a look at :

bugs.bug_description:
Currently when we restore the buffer pool from a dump and there is not enough space in the buffer pool (e.g. if we do this on a slave with less RAM and hence, the lower size of the pool), XtraDB starts flushing pages to free more space as it would normally do.

However, the more optimal behavior when restoring from a dump would be to just stop loading.

| log_slow_rate_limit                     | 1

such as replication thread or have app with few persistent connection.

Make an option something like log_slow_rate_limit_by  which can be either "session" or "query" with session default to be same as now. Though I want to set it to "query" if I want to be sampling done on per query basics.

currently it is done in single thread but in big size ( I observed 236K IO requests).

bugs.bug_description:
Make it possible to disable index usage by optimizer.  This is to be used to validate if index can be dropped or not.

In many cases it is hard to ensure index is not used and if it is dropped wrongly adding the index may be very expensive.

This is especially issue with XtraDB/Innodb plugin which can drop index instantly so it can be done with no downtime, adding indexes though require a lot

bugs.bug_description:
Once Google patch measured IO latencies for requests.  It would be good to add this to Percona Server.  I think just total wait time is enough (the average can be computed for every interval)

I would like to see something like 

innodb_io_read_time  (foreground reads)
innodb_io_write_time  (buffer pool write)
innodb_io_log_write_time (time taken to write and fsync log)

This will help to understand if IO system is the bottleneck.  If system is operating under normal load I would see log_write_time being very log (going to BBU cache) same as write_time and read time being not much more than disk seek.

bugs.bug_description:
A server I recently installed percona-server on which I rebooted yesterday had suddenly two instances of percona-server running: one working OK and one dying every couple of minutes.

I tracked this down to the fact that there are two scripts that start mysql when rebooting a server if you upgrade an existing mysql-server:

one in /etc/init.d, provided by percona-server, and
one in /etc/init, provided by mysql-server-5.1 (the original ubuntu package)

root@rinske:/etc/init# dpkg -S /etc/init.d/mysql
percona-server-server-5.1: /etc/init.d/mysql
root@rinske:/etc/init# dpkg -S /etc/init/mysql.conf
mysql-server-5.1: /etc/init/mysql.conf

Since the lucid mysql-server upstart scripts are perfectly capable of starting mysql, can they be incorporated in the package for lucid instead of the /etc/rc*  links?

Upstart provides the restart-if-crashed functionality of mysqld_safe (though I suppose that isn't a discussion that should be held here).

bugs.bug_description:
Innodb has design limitation which makes DROP TABLE very slow with large buffer pool:

http://bugs.mysql.com/bug.php?id=51325

This is serious problem for applications which use many transient tables (create/drop a lot of Innodb Tables)

As a workaround one can create tables in main tablespace which is a lot faster.   

Having innodb_file_per_table as session variable would allow to have self contained scripts which chose to create tables
in main Innodb tablespace only for duration of their operation.

The benchmark result about complicated queries (like TPC-H) should become better.

bugs.bug_description:
For example, as currently implemented:
mysql> show create table INNODB_BUFFER_POOL_PAGES\G
*************************** 1. row ***************************
       Table: INNODB_BUFFER_POOL_PAGES
Create Table: CREATE TEMPORARY TABLE `INNODB_BUFFER_POOL_PAGES` (
  `page_type` varchar(64) DEFAULT NULL,
  `space_id` bigint(21) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
  `page_no` bigint(21) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
  `lru_position` bigint(21) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
  `fix_count` bigint(21) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
  `flush_type` bigint(21) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '0'
) ENGINE=MEMORY DEFAULT CHARSET=utf8
1 row in set (0.00 sec)

From the manual page:
http://www.percona.com/docs/wiki/percona-server:features:innodb_buffer_pool_pages

It would be better as:
CREATE TEMPORARY TABLE `INNODB_BUFFER_POOL_PAGES` (
  `page_type` varchar(64) DEFAULT NULL COMMENT 'Type of the page',
  `space_id` bigint(21) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '0' COMMENT 'Which tablespace is the page located in',
  `page_no` bigint(21) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
  `lru_position` bigint(21) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
  `fix_count` bigint(21) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
  `flush_type` bigint(21) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '0' COMMENT 'type of the last flush of the page (0:LRU 2:flush_list)'
) ENGINE=MEMORY DEFAULT CHARSET=utf8

I didn't fill in the comments for all the fields.  I assume you can define the comment in the definition of the table in the C code, as far as I know, all tables support comments.

bugs.bug_description:
This is proposal from Peter

Current incremental backups are pain for large databases because they require complete scan.  The idea is to add the feature which will be able 
to track changes in the database and only copy data if it was changed.    To maintain this server need to be modified to have an option to maintain
the log of pages changed enabled by option  innodb_modified_pages_log=<file_prefix>

Innodb when will create series of log file     ib_modified_log.000001   (and increasing numbers) with  numbers increasing on each MySQL Restart
or reaching  certain size (for example 1GB) (in the future we might add feature to rotate them)

The log file will contain records containing  TIMESTAMP, LSN_FROM, LST_TO <LIST OF PAGES+TABLESPACES FLUSHED>.   Each block should have length and
checksum in the start of the block so if partial block have been written during the crash it is detected.

When MySQL is to about to write series of pages to the disk  (ie when they are picked for double write buffer)  we store list of pages updated and 
LSN number  and fsync() before pages are written to their appropriate locations on disk.

We store both LSN_FROM and LSN_TO as checkpoint LSN to be able to catch the case if data was corrupted in some way - for example if we temporary disabled
this functionality by mistake and when enabled this back we'll have the gap in the ranges  (the next LSN_FROM will not match LSN_TO in previous record) this
means the log will be unusable.

Integration With Xtrabackup:


Xtrabackup will have the option to read this set of log file.  It will check the first record in each log file to understand from which log file it should start and when will
identify the last LSN_FROM which is smaller than supplied argument.  When it will scan the log files to build the list of pages which need to be copied, sorting it by
tablespace number.   Many pages will be seen multiple times in the log file but they still need to be copied only once. 

Xtrabackup will not need to enable or disable anything on server so multiple backup processes can continue to operate absolutely independently. 

Size Calculation:

Assuming we're writing 100MB/sec of flushing, (over 8TB/day)  which is 6400 pages per second.  They are flushed in 100 page blocks (double write) in this case we'll need to write:

64*(8+4+16+100*8)    = ~ 53KB/sec     or  about 4.5GB per day.   It also contains about 1/200 of data written from buffer pool to the disk which I consider acceptable overhead.


If we consider more typical example for such case,  1TB database, about 10GB of data changed per day.     10G of changes will require some 60MB of tracking changes, which in 
case Incremental backups are done as daily backup during a week will contain less than 500MB in total, which is  0.05% of total database size.
bugs.bug_title: Feature request: InnoDB changes tracking for incremental backup
bugs.title: Bug #742162 in Percona Server: "Feature request: InnoDB changes tracking for incremental backup"

bugs.bug_description:
As part of work on optimized flush mode we need to add support for multiple write request modes to Innodb
We can have:

innodb_flush_merge_mode=none|seq_dirty|neighbors|seq_all 

note is essentially no merging same as innodb_flush_neighbors=0;   seq_dirty is the new mode which is implemented which only me merges sequential write request.  neighbors is default mode Innodb uses now

We should investigate if it is possible to develop seq_all mode in which case  clean pages are also flushed if we can get more bulky writes and merge more clean pages, for example

.DCDCCDPDCDCCC.

Where P is target page and D dirty page and C clean page, "." is page not in buffer pool.  
With seq_dirty we can merge "DPD" together as one 3 page write,  in seq_all we can merge
"DCDCCDPDCD" together flushing 6 dirty pages for cost of single write.
bugs.bug_title: Implement option to control write merge mode

Mar 31 17:50:19 localhost mysqld: 110331 17:50:19 [Note] Flashcache setup error is : ioctl failed

I think it would be best to suppress these unless flashcache device actually exists. Another way to approach this could be a flag to explicitly enable flashcache in Percona Server though I'm guessing that may break existing flashcache installations after upgrade.

Aurimas

bugs.bug_description:
Currently innodb physically writes zeroes to file for -- 

innodb table space creation (ibdata), log file creation(ib_logfile*), innodb single tablespace creation (ibd), extension of table space files (both ibdata and ibd)  

--- all of  which make the process really slow. So I decided to add fallocate support to all of the above. Even though benefit should come from fast creation of initial files*, most benefit will be visible in extension, since it can actively affect the queries and also adds overhead with mutexes etc. Fallocate is by far a O(1) operation. I have tested it on XFS/ext4 filesystem  on my box for small sizes and results are really good. But needs to be benchmarked on better systems.

The code is here (commits from 3547 to 3550)  -- https://code.launchpad.net/~raghavendra-prabhu/+junk/mysql-server-fallocate  and is based on latest mysql server tip from here -- bazaar.launchpad.net/%2Bbranch/mysql-server/ . It needs to be built with -DWITH_FALLOCATE=ON to cmake, system should also support it (added a feature test for that).

* Earlier, I have seen a case of innodb ibdata file being set to 2-3 TB and that physical writing of zeroes taking hours even on RAID, so on a downtime or fresh boxes adding time significantly.

PS: The only caveat so far is that on old ext4 (<= 2009) systems, Direct I/O with fallocate falls back to buffered IO. XFS doesn't have any such issues.
bugs.bug_title: Fallocate support in innodb
bugs.title: Bug #892831 in Percona Server: "Fallocate support in innodb"

bugs.bug_description:
When using InnoDB_trx_id to filter out statements issued by a certain transaction, it is not easy to get the time transaction started and finished exactly, espcially if connections are reused by many transactions. Had InnoDB_trx_id been logged for BEGIN/COMMIT statement, that would help me save a great deal of time in this process.

AFAIK, there's no InnoDB_trx_id when BEGIN statement is run since transaction is only started when first statement is run against InnoDB table, however it should definitely be known at the time of COMMIT.

Here's a sample slow query log entry for BEGIN/COMMIT statement:

# Time: 111129 13:35:25.0000307027
# User@Host: s[s] @ a [172.16.0.126]
# Thread_id: 3683352  Schema: s  Last_errno: 0  Killed: 0
# Query_time: 0.000017  Lock_time: 0.000000  Rows_sent: 0  Rows_examined: 0  Rows_affected: 0  Rows_read: 1
# Bytes_sent: 11  Tmp_tables: 0  Tmp_disk_tables: 0  Tmp_table_sizes: 0
# QC_Hit: No  Full_scan: No  Full_join: No  Tmp_table: No  Tmp_table_on_disk: No
# Filesort: No  Filesort_on_disk: No  Merge_passes: 0
# No InnoDB statistics available for this query
SET timestamp=1322573725;
BEGIN;

# Time: 111129 13:35:25.0000305323
# User@Host: s[s] @ a [172.16.0.126]
# Thread_id: 3683352  Schema: s  Last_errno: 0  Killed: 0
# Query_time: 0.000565  Lock_time: 0.000000  Rows_sent: 0  Rows_examined: 0  Rows_affected: 0  Rows_read: 1
# Bytes_sent: 11  Tmp_tables: 0  Tmp_disk_tables: 0  Tmp_table_sizes: 0
# QC_Hit: No  Full_scan: No  Full_join: No  Tmp_table: No  Tmp_table_on_disk: No
# Filesort: No  Filesort_on_disk: No  Merge_passes: 0
# No InnoDB statistics available for this query
SET timestamp=1322573725;
COMMIT;
bugs.bug_title: InnoDB_trx_id not logged in slow query log for BEGIN/COMMIT
bugs.title: Bug #897715 in Percona Server: "InnoDB_trx_id not logged in slow query log for BEGIN/COMMIT"

bugs.bug_description:
For mysqlbinlog client tool, when configured with -v (verbose) for row formatted binlog, the escape chars are shown with processed while not like the inserting buffer. Take examples below:

root@test 09:50:47>show create table tx;
+-------+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| Table | Create Table                                                                          |
+-------+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
| tx    | CREATE TABLE `tx` (
  `a` varchar(5) DEFAULT NULL
) ENGINE=InnoDB DEFAULT CHARSET=gbk |
+-------+---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+
1 row in set (0.01 sec)

root@test 09:50:58>insert into tx values('a\'b');
Query OK, 1 row affected (0.01 sec)

root@test 09:56:47>insert into tx values('a\tb');
Query OK, 1 row affected (0.00 sec)

root@test 10:06:01>insert into tx values('a\bb');
Query OK, 1 row affected (0.00 sec)

root@test 10:06:04>insert into tx values('a\0b');
Query OK, 1 row affected (0.00 sec)

$sudo mysqlbinlog --no-defaults /u01/mysqld/log/mysql-bin.000008 -v | grep ^'###'
### INSERT INTO test.tx
### SET
###   @1='a'b'
### INSERT INTO test.tx
### SET
###   @1='a\x09b'
### INSERT INTO test.tx
### SET
###   @1='a\x08b'
### INSERT INTO test.tx
### SET
###   @1='a\x00b'

While we changed the @1 value shown as below:

$sudo mysqlbinlog --no-defaults /u01/mysqld/log/mysql-bin.000008 -v | grep ^'###'
### INSERT INTO test.tx
### SET
###   @1='a\'b'
### INSERT INTO test.tx
### SET
###   @1='a\tb'
### INSERT INTO test.tx
### SET
###   @1='a\bb'
### INSERT INTO test.tx
### SET
###   @1='a\0b'


There is no problem for the first shown, while we expect the later shown for two reasons:
1. more readable of column values for mysqlbinlog -v
2. for some special usage (extra string from ###@1 for another usage, like constructing SQL and applying to mysqld)

We changed the verbose shown for the second usage, and everything works well.
All test case passed, as well as the newly added one.

Patch is attached for review.
bugs.bug_title: enhanced binlog row verbose shown for the escape characters
bugs.title: Bug #949965 in Percona Server: "enhanced binlog row verbose shown for the escape characters"

bugs.bug_description:
As for deadlock detect mechanism in Innodb, it's talked for long whether
we need recursive checking for deadlock for some specail scenario, such as
lots of concurrent updates for the same record.

In the Planet MySQL, it's recommended:
“InnoDB is much faster when deadlock detection is disabled for workloads with 
a lot of concurrency and contention.”

We are suffering the scenario above, in one of Taobao's core application, Item Center(IC).
Most of the time, it's okay, while for some special sales promotion(about once per month),
it's very very bad, as lots of users of Taobao participated in.

Here is the oprofile result(simulated the online scenario):
 2 Counted CPU_CLK_UNHALTED events (Clock cycles when not halted) with a unit mask of 0x00 (Unhalted core cycles) count 100000
  3 samples  %        symbol name
  4 2008672  84.8036  lock_deadlock_recursive
  5 91364     3.8573  lock_has_to_wait
  6 11216     0.4735  safe_mutex_lock
  7 9719      0.4103  ut_delay
  8 8047      0.3397  MYSQLparse(void*)
  9 7938      0.3351  lock_rec_has_to_wait_in_queue
10 7788      0.3288  code_state
11 7601      0.3209  my_strnncoll_binary
12 6703      0.2830  dict_col_get_clust_pos_noninline
13 6598      0.2786  _db_enter_
14 6451      0.2724  _db_return_
15 5733      0.2420  _db_doprnt_
16 5503      0.2323  rec_get_offsets_func
17 5325      0.2248  ha_innobase::update_row(unsigned char const*, unsigned char*)
18 5241      0.2213  mutex_spin_wait
19 4931      0.2082  build_template(row_prebuilt_struct*, THD*, st_table*, unsigned int)
20 4655      0.1965  lock_rec_convert_impl_to_expl

As you can see, it's soo bad for lock_detect_recursive function. So we added a switch
to disable the deadlock detect dynamically. For IC application, there is almost no
deadlock as business SQL logic is tuned, so there seems no risk yet.

To make the scenario repeatable, a test case is provided with the data we hit (tweak for sensitive columns) later and the related patch. Please help to have a review.
bugs.bug_title: performance tuning for deadlock detect switch
bugs.title: Bug #952920 in Percona Server: "performance tuning for deadlock detect switch "

bugs.bug_description:
There is a param replicate-rewrite-db already, for from_db.* -> to_db.*

It is useful for environment that need split tables into several dbs in master, and collect all the updates into one db in slave.

Another requirement will be spliting table into several ones in on schema,
such as split a into a_01, a_02, .... a_n, for performance issues.

There may be requirement that need to collect all the a_% data into a single table, in slave.
So if there is way to translate updates from a_% into a, it will be convenient.

Patch follow based on Percona Server 5.5.18,  offer a new param for the purpose above.
eg.
  replicate-wild-rewrite-table=test_%.abc_% -> test.abc
can translate all updates in tables that match the "test_%.abc_%" patten, into test.abc.
bugs.bug_title: a new param replicate-wild-rewrite-table for rewrite table name in slave
bugs.title: Bug #1015463 in Percona Server: "a new param replicate-wild-rewrite-table for rewrite table name in slave"

bugs.bug_description:
Replication is often interrupted because of some errors,  and the most common errors we encountered recently are  "HA_ERR_KEY_NOT_FOUND" and "HA_ERR_FOUND_DUPP_KEY".

there are two methods to handle the errors:
1). ignore the error by setting "sql_slave_skip_counter".
2).set slave_exec_mode = "idempotent"  to handle "HA_ERR_FOUND_DUPP_KEY" (overwritten the record) and "HA_ERR_KEY_NOT_FOUND"(just ignore the error).

Both methods  may lead to inconsistencies between master and slave.

if we are using row-based replication and  innodb storage engine ,  why don't we fix these errors instead of simply ignore it?

So I introduced  in a new value of slave_exec_mode:  SMART

a simple idea is :

1) HA_ERR_KEY_NOT_FOUND
       UPDATE_ROWS_EVENT:  write 'Before Image' of the record, and then update it
       DELETE_ROWS_EVENT:     write the record and then delete it , or just ignore  the error

2)HA_ERR_FOUND_DUPP_KEY
      WRITE_ROWS_EVENT:      just overwrite the record
      UPDATE_ROWS_EVENT :  delete the duplicated record and then update (if the error is caused because of duplicated unique key and the table also has a primary key ,  the fix may failed and all changes can be rollback)

The attached file is a simple patch based on Percona-Server-5.5.24-rel26.0, and it is still under the testing.
bugs.bug_title: a new value of slave_exec_mode to handle slave error such as "HA_ERR_KEY_NOT_FOUND" or "HA_ERR_FOUND_DUPP_KEY"
bugs.title: Bug #1018685 in Percona Server: "a new value of slave_exec_mode to handle slave error such as "HA_ERR_KEY_NOT_FOUND" or "HA_ERR_FOUND_DUPP_KEY""

bugs.bug_description:
As we know, query_cache overhead for LOCK can only be avoided when start-up mysql with query_cache_type is 0. That's what Percona contributed: http://www.percona.com/doc/percona-server/5.5/performance/query_cache_enhance.html?id=percona-server:features:query_cache_enhance#disabling_the_cache_completely

That's a nice work. However, if we want the query cache back, the mysqld must be restarted with query_cache_type=1. That's the problem, and some customers faced the scenarios.

I looked into the code, and found it might be resolved without the limitation of restarted mysqld.  If we call is_disabled with a traced query_cache_type and combined with current setting query_cache_type, it's Okay to judge whether we could get the same result as old is_disabled function in Query_cache class.

Detail info could refer to qc.patch, which is based on Percona-5.5.18
bugs.bug_title: dynamic setting query_cache_type but keeping the benefit of keeping away of overhead LOCK if query cache type is 0
bugs.title: Bug #1021131 in Percona Server: "dynamic setting query_cache_type but keeping the benefit of keeping away of overhead LOCK if query cache type is 0"

bugs.bug_description:
Twitter has implemented a few changes to mysql and mysqld safe that help prevent imbalanced memory allocation across numa nodes.   Implementing these in Percona Server would be a huge win for my company, as we have been having issues with Numa imbalance.  We have found that modifying the mysqld_safe to do numactl --interleave all has helped, but has not resolved the issue totally.

Here are the twitter patches that I would like to request be implemented in Percona Server.

https://github.com/twitter/mysql/commit/19cf63c596c0146a72583998d138190cc285df5c
https://github.com/twitter/mysql/commit/76e70595e32dc30b1e8de7c3bf86e54cc9cea769

bugs.bug_description: Add counters into SHOW PROCESSLIST for Rows_examined, Rows_sent, Rows_read -- I'm not sure what counters are available.  But I know these counters are kept for each query locally, because they are written to the slow query log.  It would be very helpful to expose them in SHOW PROCESSLIST so they could be used for estimating things such as the progress and estimated completion time of a query.
bugs.bug_title: Add Rows_examined into SHOW PROCESSLIST
bugs.title: Bug #589491 in Percona Server: "Add Rows_examined into SHOW PROCESSLIST"

bugs.bug_description:
Currently Fast Warmup in XtraDB is inconvenient to use.  It has to be done more user friendly

- Add  innodb_buffer_pool_dump_period variable which will specify how frequently Innodb will dump its contents (page numbers) to the file.
Make sure the dump operation is not intrusive to system performance

- On startup if dump file has been discovered Innodb should load pages specified in it in memory in optimal order and delete file (so if you disable automatic page dump it will be done only once at startup.

-  Option  --innodb_wait_for_preload should be implemented to allow preload to be synchronous on start only starting listening on MySQL socket after preload is completed (and hence server can respond fast to queries)  By default this option should be disable and preload should happen in background after server is started. 

- Preload should stop as soon as there is no empty pages in Innodb Buffer pool.
bugs.bug_title: Improve Fast Warmup
bugs.title: Bug #590294 in Percona Server: "Improve Fast Warmup"

bugs.bug_description:
Right now it's very hard to tell whether a connection has an open transaction.  We can parse InnoDB status, but it's not even reliable.  It would be very useful to know this so it could be monitored and alerted if there is a long-running idle transaction, for example.

- Add a Transaction_open status variable or similar, which should be 1 or 0.
- Add Txn to SHOW PROCESSLIST (also 0 or 1).
bugs.bug_title: Add features to show whether a connection is in a transaction
bugs.title: Bug #599503 in Percona Server: "Add features to show whether a connection is in a transaction"

bugs.bug_description:
MySQL Revision 47 went away this morning with nothing in the error log except this:

100702 09:31:19 mysqld_safe Number of processes running now: 0
100702 09:31:19 mysqld_safe mysqld restarted

We brought mysql up again, checked all tables, then brought it down and upgraded to Revision 51. Now our slaves will not start, reporting:

Last_IO_Error: Got fatal error 1236 from master when reading data from binary log: 'Could not find first log file name in binary log index file'

The binary logfiles haven't moved, permissions haven't changed, and if I FLUSH LOGS on the master, it properly creates a new binary file in the expected place and updates the index file accordingly. The first line in /var/log/mysql/binary/mysql-bin.index is:

/var/log/mysql/binary/mysql-bin.000132

and that file exists and is parseable by mysqlbinlog without errors. The relevant entries in /etc/my.cnf are:

log-bin = /var/log/mysql/binary/mysql-bin
log-bin-index = /var/log/mysql/binary/mysql-bin.index
bugs.bug_title: Revision 47 crash, Revision 51 upgrade, now getting error 1236
bugs.title: Bug #601135 in Percona Server: "Revision 47 crash, Revision 51 upgrade, now getting error 1236"

bugs.bug_description:
Hi,

We have recently tried to migrate to 5.1.47-rel11.1 OR 5.0.91-b22 versions of Percona binaries but kept having a strange unicode issue around collations:

Illegal mix of collations (utf8_general_ci,IMPLICIT) and (utf8_unicode_ci,IMPLICIT) for operation '='


However, this has never been an issue before, our entire database uses utf8_general_ci and no where is there any collation marked as utf8_general_ci.

When we migrate back to the standard MySQL binaries, the issue goes away.

Seems to be an issue with Percona binaries.
bugs.bug_title: Unicode Collation mixmatch issues with latest releases
bugs.title: Bug #602045 in Percona Server: "Unicode Collation mixmatch issues with latest releases"

bugs.bug_description:
Not really sure it is a bug, but to me it seems that way.

Looks like executing a TRUNCATE table repeatedly inside a SP consumes too much memory that is not returned.

How to repeat:
[code]
CREATE TABLE testTruncate (col1 int not null, col2 int not null, col3 boolean not null) ENGINE = InnoDB;

DELIMITER //

CREATE PROCEDURE testTruncateMemory()
BEGIN
    DECLARE it SMALLINT UNSIGNED DEFAULT 1;

    TEST:LOOP
       TRUNCATE testTruncate;
       SET it=it+1;
       IF(it=500)THEN
            LEAVE TEST;
       END IF;
END LOOP TEST;
END//

[/code]

Use top to monitor memory used by mysqld process.
CALL testTruncateMemory();
watch memory grow > ~20M for every call to SP.

Is this really a bug? Do I missed anything? Is this normal/expected behaviour?
I tried with percona server versions:
Server version: 5.1.45-87.karmic.34-log (Percona SQL Server (GPL), XtraDB 10)
Server version: 5.1.47-rel11.1-log (Percona Server (GPL), 11.1 , Revision 51)
and in both versions the behaviour is repeated.

Tried with mysql:
Server version: 5.1.48 MySQL Community Server (GPL)
And no extra memory is needed to execute procedure
bugs.bug_title: TRUNCATE table consumes too much memory

bugs.bug_description:
After upgrade from Percona Server 10.2 some of mysqld's started to segfault on queries like:

show table status like 'bl\_kindsd'\G

OPTIMIZE TABLE bl_kidsd;    resulted also in segfault.


After downgrade to 10.2 I was able to get SHOW STATUS runinng:

mysql> show table status like 'bl\_kindsd'\G
*************************** 1. row ***************************
           Name: bl_kindsd
         Engine: InnoDB
        Version: 10
     Row_format: Compact
           Rows: 2
 Avg_row_length: 8192
    Data_length: 16384
Max_data_length: 0
   Index_length: 0
      Data_free: 0
 Auto_increment: 18446744073709551615
    Create_time: 2010-08-03 00:33:52
    Update_time: NULL
     Check_time: NULL
      Collation: utf8_polish_ci
       Checksum: NULL
 Create_options:
        Comment:
1 row in set (0.00 sec)

OPTIMIZE TABLE corrected problem with auto_increment counter and after another upgrade to 5.1.47-11.2 everything works like a charm. Question is, why 5.1.47-11.2 is segfaulting in this situation and why it cannot repair such error.

bugs.bug_title: mysqld crash "InnoDB: Failing assertion: new_index"
bugs.title: Bug #613471 in Percona Server: "mysqld crash "InnoDB: Failing assertion: new_index""

bugs.bug_description:
We had a double server crash.

It looks like it happened during some massive Magento webshop rebuild/update.
Magento is known for heavily abusing the database, doing thousands of single row INSERTS/DELETES.
The crash happend during a simple insert so it is not easy to reproduce.
INSERT INTO `customer_entity_varchar` (`entity_type_id`, `entity_id`, `attribute_id`, `value`) VALUES ('1','2','4','396b8618476a85d05a2749ddee9d1f0b:wJ') ON DUPLICATE KEY UPDATE `value`=VALUES(`value`)

In both cases there was an open transaction affecting 30k+ rows (you can see it is rolled back after restart).

The crashes affect a few hundreds of our clients, so it is very important for us to get a stable server.
We will be very happy if we could help with further resolving this bug.

Kindest regards.


Error log follows:


100812  2:42:31 - mysqld got signal 11 ;
This could be because you hit a bug. It is also possible that this binary
or one of the libraries it was linked against is corrupt, improperly built,
or misconfigured. This error can also be caused by malfunctioning hardware.
We will try our best to scrape up some info that will hopefully help diagnose
the problem, but since we have already crashed, something is definitely wrong
and this may fail.

read_buffer_size=131072

max_threads=750
threads_connected=16

key_buffer_size + (read_buffer_size + sort_buffer_size)*max_threads = 1910345 K
bytes of memory
Hope that's ok; if not, decrease some variables in the equation.

bugs.bug_title: crash when using Partition datetime in sub in query
bugs.title: Bug #624691 in Percona Server: "crash when using Partition datetime in sub in query "

bugs.bug_description:
MySQL's packages include 

MySQL-shared-community
MySQL-shared-compat - which includes libmysqlclient.so.15 and libmysqlclient.so.16

Percona server has:
Percona-Server-shared - which includes libmysqlclient.so.16 but not libmysqlclient.so.15

Because of dynamic linking, other programs may require libmysqlclient.so.15 (for example, in one specific case, postfix needed it).

Please build Percona-Server-shared to include libmysqlclient.so.15 (specifically Percona-Server-shared-51-5.1.47-rel11.1.51.rhel5.x86_64.rpm is the package I tested)

Workaround:  On a clean server, install Percona Server binaries except -shared:
Percona-Server-client-51-5.1.47-rel11.1.51.rhel5.x86_64.rpm
Percona-Server-devel-51-5.1.47-rel11.1.51.rhel5.x86_64.rpm
Percona-Server-server-51-5.1.47-rel11.1.51.rhel5.x86_64.rpm
Percona-Server-test-51-5.1.47-rel11.1.51.rhel5.x86_64.rpm

then --force install:
MySQL-shared-compat-5.1.47-1.rhel5.x86_64.rpm

then --force install:
Percona-Server-shared-51-5.1.47-rel11.1.51.rhel5.x86_64.rpm

There's no need to have MySQL-shared-compat just for libmysqlclient.so.15
bugs.bug_title: libmysqlclient.so.15 missing from Percona-Server-shared
bugs.title: Bug #632684 in Percona Server: "libmysqlclient.so.15 missing from Percona-Server-shared"

bugs.bug_description:
A replication slave from MySQL-server-percona-highperf-5.0.87-b20.29.rhel5 to Percona-Server-server-51-5.1.50-rel11.4.111.rhel5 (both 64 bit) seems to be taking a long time before simple truncate table statements, eg:

| 15533 | system user |           | email_production | Connect | 36665 | init                             | truncate table email_bounce_subs |
to
| 15533 | system user |           | email_production | Connect | 36719 | init                             | truncate table email_bounce_subs |

and

| 17405 | system user |           | firelink_production | Connect | 33301 | init                             | TRUNCATE TABLE tmp_publishable_popularities |
to
| 17405 | system user |           | firelink_production | Connect | 33303 | init                             | TRUNCATE TABLE tmp_publishable_popularities |

Expectation is that truncates of small tables would not create noticeable pauses on slave.

Both slave and master running on ext3 centos 5.5 current.  Both large (24G-40G innodb buffer) dell servers, reasonably tuned, single use systems.  I am considering rolling back slave to MySQL-server-percona-highperf-5.0.87-b20.29.rhel5 to see if it resolves the issue.

Hello!

We are having mysqld crashes in our production servers
Server version: 5.1.47-rel11.1-log (Percona Server (GPL), 11.1 , Revision 51)

After a couple of crashes, we turned on general log, and the situation is what follows:

- Tables involved -

CREATE TABLE table1 (
  `date` MEDIUMINT NOT NULL,
  `col1` INT UNSIGNED NOT NULL ,
  `col2` INT NOT NULL DEFAULT 0,
  PRIMARY KEY (`col1`,`date`),  
  CONSTRAINT `fk_table1_table2`
    FOREIGN KEY (`col1`)
    REFERENCES `table2` (`col1`)
    ON DELETE CASCADE
    ON UPDATE CASCADE
) ENGINE = InnoDB;


CREATE TABLE `table2` (
  `col1` int(10) unsigned NOT NULL,
  `col2` int(10) unsigned NOT NULL,
  `col3` varchar(45) NOT NULL,
  `col4` varchar(45) NOT NULL,
  `col5` varchar(45) NOT NULL,
  `col6` varchar(45) NOT NULL,
  `col7` varchar(45) NOT NULL,
  `col8` smallint(6) NOT NULL,
  `col9` int(10) unsigned NOT NULL,
  `col10` varchar(256) NOT NULL,
  `col11` varchar(256) NOT NULL,
  `col12` INT NOT NULL ,
  `col13` MEDIUMINT NOT NULL DEFAULT 0,
  `col14` MEDIUMINT NOT NULL,
  PRIMARY KEY (`col1`)
) ENGINE=InnoDB DEFAULT CHARSET=utf8;

CREATE TABLE `table3` (
  `col1` int(10) unsigned NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT,
  `col2` decimal(15,0) unsigned NOT NULL,
  `col3` int(10) unsigned NOT NULL,
  `col4` tinyint(1) NOT NULL DEFAULT '1',
  `col5` varchar(256) DEFAULT NULL,
  `col6` int(10) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '1',
  `col7` timestamp NULL DEFAULT NULL,
  `col8` int(11) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
  `col9` int(11) NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
  `col10` smallint(5) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '1',
  `col11` tinyint(1) NOT NULL DEFAULT '1',
  `col12` int(10) unsigned DEFAULT NULL,
  `col13` int(10) unsigned DEFAULT NULL,
  `col14` varchar(16) DEFAULT NULL,
  PRIMARY KEY (`col1`),
  UNIQUE KEY `u_col2` (`col2`),
  CONSTRAINT `fk_table3_tableX` 
  	FOREIGN KEY (`col10`) 
  	REFERENCES `tableX` (`col10`) 
  	ON UPDATE CASCADE,
  CONSTRAINT `fk_table3_tableY` 
  	FOREIGN KEY (`col6`) 
  	REFERENCES `tableY` (`col6`) 
  	ON UPDATE CASCADE,
  CONSTRAINT `fk_table3_table2` 
  	FOREIGN KEY (`col3`) 
  	REFERENCES `table2` (`col1`) 
  	ON UPDATE CASCADE
) ENGINE=InnoDB DEFAULT CHARSET=utf8;

- Trigger involved -

CREATE TRIGGER beforeUpdateTable3 BEFORE UPDATE ON table3
FOR EACH ROW
BEGIN
    INSERT INTO table1 (col1,col2,date) VALUES (NEW.col3,NEW.col9,DATE_FORMAT(now(),'%Y%m')) ON DUPLICATE KEY UPDATE col2 = col2 + (NEW.col9 - OLD.col9), date = DATE_FORMAT(now(),'%Y%m');
END//

18 Query     INSERT INTO table1 (col1,col2,date) VALUES (NEW.col1,NEW.col2,DATE_FORMAT(now(),'%Y%m')) ON DUPLICATE KEY UPDATE col2 = col2 + (NEW.col2 - OLD.col2), date = DATE_FORMAT(now(),'%Y%m');

Next thing is mysqld started.





What I can see in other crashes like this is that trigger from table3 is executed couple of times succesfully before mysqld server crashes. I cannot reproduce the crash but it's happening from time to time at our servers.




I didn't knew where to post, as I cannot assure this is a bug, I just need some help figuring out what is happening to find a fix/workaround.
(Some help on extracting info from the stack trace would be very nice ;) )

Thanks in advance.
bugs.bug_title: Weird mysqld crash
bugs.title: Bug #663335 in Percona Server: "Weird mysqld crash"

bugs.bug_description:
How to repeat:

Create database based on included sample.sql.

Issue following SQL:

SET @OLD_FOREIGN_KEY_CHECKS=@@FOREIGN_KEY_CHECKS, FOREIGN_KEY_CHECKS=0;
ALTER TABLE `yourdatabase`.`products_slots` DROP INDEX `fk_products_has_categories_products1` ;

On latest stable Percona Server (5.1.51-rel11.5) MySQL is crashing - part of error log can be downloaded from here:

http://ksiazek.info/buglog.txt 

On 5.5.6 I was also able to reproduce this error. I've installed and tested latest Community Edition server (5.1.52). It didn't crash (which is good and preferable behaviour), instead it returned an error:

mysql> ALTER TABLE `baza60017_costa`.`products_slots`
    -> DROP INDEX `fk_products_has_categories_products1` ;

ERROR 1025 (HY000): Error on rename of './baza60017_costa/#sql-6646_3' to './baza60017_costa/products_slots' (errno: 150)

SHOW INNODB STATUS returned with following info:

------------------------
LATEST FOREIGN KEY ERROR
------------------------
101102 12:50:29 Error in foreign key constraint of table baza60017_costa/products_slots:
there is no index in the table which would contain
the columns as the first columns, or the data types in the
table do not match the ones in the referenced table
or one of the ON ... SET NULL columns is declared NOT NULL. Constraint:
,
  CONSTRAINT "fk_products_has_categories_products1" FOREIGN KEY ("products_id") REFERENCES "products" ("id") ON DELETE CASCADE ON UPDATE CASCADE


Yup, I know isuing this statement is not a good idea, but our client did it. it shouldn't result in complete database server crash. Standard InnoDB recovery wasn't able to deal with it, only way to start InnoDB was to run with innodb_force_recovery=6 and drop `product_slots` table.

bugs.bug_description:
Hi

I have been advised to log this as a bug, after bringing up my results in the forum http://forum.percona.com/index.php?t=rview&goto=6390

In summary:

Our server is :
Freebsd 8.1-RELEASE AMD64
2.66Ghz Quad Core QPi (8 virtual cores)
16GB DDR3
4 x 73Gb raid 6

New install, not being used for anything else.

Installed Mysql 5.1.52 standard install (without plugin) + benchmarked
Uninstalled Mysql 5.1, installed Percona Server + bencharked

Compared performance on a standard benchmark using super-smack
Queries per second is consistently slower on Percona, compared to Mysql 5.1 with without 'innodb plugin'
I have also tried using my own 'real life' queries with the same results


Test:
I am running a standard benchmark using super-smack:
The system is at 0% CPU usage and 0% I/O usage before the tests are performed

super-smack -d mysql update-select.smack 100 10000
super-smack -d mysql update-select.smack 150 10000

/etc/my.cnf values can be seen in the forum post, along with the query I used for the 'real world' tests

http://forum.percona.com/index.php?t=rview&goto=6390#msg_6390

bugs.bug_description:
Using Percona-Server-5.1.51 in a mysqlsandbox(the on launchpad patched for other .tar file names) I try to follow the examples fro exporting/importing tables - not yet to another machine but into the same sandboxed percona server. All things seems fine until I run alter table <table_name> import tablespace; Then the client is loosing the connection to the server.

I am testing this on ubuntu 10.10. I have used *.deb file for xtrabackup and launchpad checkout of mysqlsandbox and the x64 version of the stable percona server

The exact error I get is this:
mysql [localhost] {msandbox} ((none)) > alter table test.export_test import tablespace;
ERROR 2013 (HY000): Lost connection to MySQL server during query

bugs.bug_description:
I'm running Percona SQL server & client 5.0 (5.0.91-percona-b22.lucid.0) on Ubuntu Lucid, and I've found I can't build packages against it because there is no dev package for 5.0. The libmysqlclient-dev package depends on the 5.1 client lib. For me it means that 'gem install mysql' breaks as it can't find the necessary libs.
I do plan on upgrading to 5.1 soon, but in the mean time is there a workaround or fix for this?

bugs.bug_description:
userstat.patch porting of this revision seems wrong.
patch to innodb/ of 5.1 should be removed.
Because it is for built-in InnoDB of before 5.1.
(In addition, the porting seems wrong. :-( )

innodb_stats.patch already contains patch for ha_innodb.cc ported already from innodb_plugin/.

userstat.patch should not touch innodb/ at all.

and inserting this patch to the front of 'series' file makes the port/upgrading process more complex a little in the next version.

bugs.bug_description:
Completely unable to install due to dependency requirements not being met.  percona-server-common supposedly provides mysql-common, but it doesn't provide a version number sufficient to install libmysqlclient16, which is also required.

# apt-get install percona-server-server-5.1 percona-server-client-5.1 percona-server-common
Reading package lists... Done
Building dependency tree       
Reading state information... Done
percona-server-common is already the newest version.
Some packages could not be installed. This may mean that you have
requested an impossible situation or if you are using the unstable
distribution that some required packages have not yet been created
or been moved out of Incoming.
The following information may help to resolve the situation:

The following packages have unmet dependencies:
  percona-server-client-5.1: Depends: libmysqlclient16 (>= 5.1.54-12.5-188.lucid) but 5.1.41-3ubuntu12.8 is to be installed
  percona-server-common: Conflicts: mysql-common
                         Conflicts: mysql-common-4.1
E: Broken packages







# apt-get install percona-server-server-5.1 percona-server-client-5.1 percona-server-common libmysqlclient16
Reading package lists... Done
Building dependency tree       
Reading state information... Done
percona-server-common is already the newest version.
Some packages could not be installed. This may mean that you have
requested an impossible situation or if you are using the unstable
distribution that some required packages have not yet been created
or been moved out of Incoming.
The following information may help to resolve the situation:

The following packages have unmet dependencies:
  libmysqlclient16: Depends: mysql-common (>= 5.1.41-3ubuntu12.8)
  percona-server-client-5.1: Depends: libmysqlclient16 (>= 5.1.54-12.5-188.lucid) but 5.1.41-3ubuntu12.8 is to be installed
E: Broken packages

bugs.bug_description:
When using Percona Server 5.1.53 with MySQL workbench, databases other than the default do not show their tables. The Tables, Views and Routines folders just show "fetching...". 

This does not happen with the vanilla Oracle MySQL.

bugs.bug_description:
Hi!

We use Percona Server (GPL), 12.4 , Revision 181 (5.1.53-rel12.4)
on
Linux 2.6.32-5-vserver-amd64 #1 SMP Tue Jun 1 05:57:35 UTC 2010 x86_64 GNU/Linux

Percona server regullary crashes (1-3 times per day).
Contents of mysqld.log:

110119 12:51:50 - mysqld got signal 11 ;
This could be because you hit a bug. It is also possible that this binary
or one of the libraries it was linked against is corrupt, improperly built,
or misconfigured. This error can also be caused by malfunctioning hardware.
We will try our best to scrape up some info that will hopefully help diagnose
the problem, but since we have already crashed, something is definitely wrong
and this may fail.

key_buffer_size=1073741824
read_buffer_size=2097152
max_used_connections=372
max_threads=2000
threads_connected=369
It is possible that mysqld could use up to
key_buffer_size + (read_buffer_size + sort_buffer_size)*max_threads = 9262310 K
bytes of memory
Hope that's ok; if not, decrease some variables in the equation.

I untar'd the file and created sandbox, but mysqld would not start. Manually ran mysqld_safe and recorded following message in log file:

110203 09:33:15 mysqld_safe Starting mysqld daemon with databases from /opt/sandbox/msb_5_1_53/data

110203 09:33:15 mysqld_safe mysqld from pid file /opt/sandbox/msb_5_1_53/data/mysql_sandbox5153.pid ended


I tried same process for 5.1.53-12.4 binary, and had no problems.

bugs.bug_description:
XtraDB support >4GB logfile.
Though for the normal ~4GB file  around 25% margine is good (<1GB),
for the >4GB file  the around 25% might be too large.
(e.g. if 16GB, margin is around 4GB?)

The margin should be adjusted for keep around 1GB for >4GB.

----(original)----
Facebook commit http://bazaar.launchpad.net/~mysqlatfacebook/mysqlatfacebook/5.1/revision/3625
contains implementation for innodb_sync_checkpoint_limit feature.
We need to look into porting it to Percona Server.

bugs.bug_description:
We had discussion with Baron and as outcome, we need to rename next variables:

LOG_SLOW_TIMESTAMP_EVERY 
to log_slow_timestamp_always

LOG_WARNINGS_SILENCE to
LOG_WARNINGS_suppress

SLOW_QUERY_LOG_MICROSECONDS_TIMESTAMP
That should be slow_query_log_timestamp_precision=<second,microsecond>

> USE_GLOBAL_LOG_SLOW_CONTROL

I think that should be slow_query_log_use_global_control.

> USERSTAT_RUNNING

Change to userstat=<on,off>

to correspond to MariaDB
bugs.bug_title: Rename general variables in 5.5
bugs.title: Bug #721608 in Percona Server: "Rename general variables in 5.5"

bugs.bug_description:
After discussion with Baron, we should change names of following variables in 5.5:

INNODB_AUTO_LRU_DUMP
to
innodb_buffer_pool_restore_at_startup

INNODB_EXPAND_IMPORT
to
innodb_use_xtrabackup_table_import (?)

INNODB_OVERWRITE_RELAY_LOG_INFO
to
innodb_recovery_update_relay_log

INNODB_PASS_CORRUPT_TABLE
to
innodb_corrupt_table_action=assert|block (?)

And next status variables:
> INNODB_CHECKPOINT_AGE
> INNODB_CHECKPOINT_MAX_AGE
> INNODB_CHECKPOINT_TARGET_AGE

Should  be
INNODB_CHECKPOINT_AGE
INNODB_CHECKPOINT_AGE_MAX
INNODB_CHECKPOINT_AGE_TARGET

bugs.title: Bug #721611 in Percona Server: "Change XtraDB variables in 5.5"

bugs.bug_description:
we have INNODB_ROW_LOCK_NUMBERS status variable

from source code it is
+       export_vars.innodb_row_lock_numbers
+               = lock_sys->rec_num;

 as I understand it is count of records locks applied at given point of time.

If my understanding is correct we should rename it to
Innodb_current_row_locks

(@b) SET a=REVERSE(@b)' failed: 1115: Unknown character set: 'ucs2'

The result from queries just before the failure was:

LOAD DATA INFILE 't1.txt' IGNORE INTO TABLE t1 SET col0=col0;
SELECT * FROM t1;
col0
test

bugs.bug_description:
When upgrading percona-server-server-5.1 "percona-server-server-5.1.postinst" runs /bin/bash /usr/bin/mysql_install_db --rpm 2>&1 | $ERR_LOGGER to ensure system tables exist.
I may create bin-log files if they were enabled in my.cnf before.
If there is no "user=mysql" option in [mysqld] section, the bin-logs are owned by root.

However when MySQL is started by mysql.server (e.g. /etc/init.d/mysql) group [mysql.server] is processed where "user=mysql" may be specified.

Root owner of the log files prevents mysqld to start. It can't read the last log due to "permission denied" error.

bugs.bug_description:
Currently, InnoDB fast index creation can only be used when explicitly creating or dropping indexes.

We can make use of that optimization in mysqldump and ALTER TABLE / OPTIMIZE TABLE. Namely:

1. mysqldump should be updated to dump InnoDB tables so that secondary indexes are created after loading the data.

2. When ALTER TABLE requires a table copy, it can optimize copying the data by temporarily dropping secondary keys before copying and recreating them after it.

3. Since OPTIMIZE TABLE is performed as ALTER TABLE internally, it will benefit from the same optimization as well.

References:

http://www.mysqlperformanceblog.com/2010/12/09/thinking-about-running-optimize-on-your-innodb-table-stop/
http://bugs.mysql.com/bug.php?id=49120
http://bugs.mysql.com/bug.php?id=57583
bugs.bug_title: Make use of InnoDB fast index creation in mysqldump, ALTER TABLE and OPTIMIZE TABLE

bugs.bug_description:
The innodb_purge_thread patch accepts a value up to 64 for the innodb_use_purge_thread variable. mtr --suite=innodb_plugin crashes quickly when it is set to 60 with the error:
110408 23:08:43  InnoDB: Assertion failure in thread 139699818366720 in file ./include/trx0roll.ic line 37
InnoDB: Failing assertion: n < arr->n_cells

And the stack is:

(gdb) where
#0  0x00007ffff6861ba5 in raise (sig=<value optimized out>)
    at ../nptl/sysdeps/unix/sysv/linux/raise.c:64
#1  0x00007ffff68656b0 in abort () at abort.c:92
#2  0x000000000093d264 in trx_undo_arr_get_nth_info (arr=0x1a0e738, n=32)
    at ./include/trx0roll.ic:37
#3  0x0000000000937315 in trx_purge_arr_store_info (trx_no=784, undo_no=21)
    at trx/trx0purge.c:99
#4  0x000000000093981c in trx_purge_fetch_next_rec (roll_ptr=0x7fffdd501d38, 
    cell=0x1a1f430, heap=0x1a1f8e0) at trx/trx0purge.c:1075
#5  0x00000000009194ee in row_purge (node=0x1a1f3e8, thr=0x1a1f248)
    at row/row0purge.c:623
#6  0x00000000009196d4 in row_purge_step (thr=0x1a1f248) at row/row0purge.c:700
#7  0x00000000008fd48f in que_thr_step (thr=0x1a1f248) at que/que0que.c:1248
#8  0x00000000008fd68f in que_run_threads_low (thr=0x1a1f248)
    at que/que0que.c:1306
#9  0x00000000008fd7a3 in que_run_threads (thr=0x1a1f248) at que/que0que.c:1343
#10 0x0000000000939dc6 in trx_purge_worker (worker_id=16)
    at trx/trx0purge.c:1248
#11 0x000000000092ea05 in srv_purge_worker_thread (arg=0x109bf88)
    at srv/srv0srv.c:3580
#12 0x00007ffff7bc6971 in start_thread (arg=<value optimized out>)
    at pthread_create.c:304

The number of cells in arr is UNIV_MAX_PARALLELISM, so the max value for innodb_use_purge_threads should be UNIV_MAX_PARALLELISM

bugs.bug_description:
srv_purge_thread/trx_purge does not wait for threads to exit from the previous round of srv_purge_worker_thread/trx_purge_worker. The worker threads from srv_purge_worker_thread/trx_purge_worker might still be doing work and using purge_sys->view while trx_purge concurrently calls read_view_close(purge_sys->view) and mem_heap_empty(purge_sys->heap). It looks like the worker threads will then end up using de-allocated memory.

My proof is code I added that uses atomic increment/decrement to count the number of active worker threads and confirm this count can be > 0 at the entry to trx_purge. By "active" worker threads I mean threads in trx_purge_worker that are currently in que_run_threads.

bugs.bug_description:
Reporting http://bugs.mysql.com/bug.php?id=60788 on Launchpad so we can track our work on it and the status of the MySQL bug locally:

Description:
According to POSIX write()/pwrite() return -1 with errno set to EINTR when those calls
are interrupted by a signal before they write any data, or return the number of bytes
written if a signal is received after successfully writing some data.

Neither of those cases are handled correctly by InnoDB. Here is an example of pwrite()
returning -1 with errno set to EINTR:

InnoDB: Error: Write to file ./test/test.ibd failed at offset 0 5308416.
InnoDB: 983040 bytes should have been written, only -1 were written.
InnoDB: Operating system error number 4.
InnoDB: Check that your OS and file system support files of this size.
InnoDB: Check also that the disk is not full or a disk quota exceeded.
InnoDB: Error number 4 means 'Interrupted system call'.
InnoDB: Some operating system error numbers are described at
InnoDB: http://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.1/en/operating-system-error-codes.html
InnoDB: Assertion failure in thread 1140169024 in file os/os0file.c line 4205
InnoDB: Failing assertion: ret
InnoDB: We intentionally generate a memory trap.

MyISAM is not affected by this problem because mysys handles those cases correctly by
restarting the write.

I think all of the above applies to reads as well.

How to repeat:
Examine the os_file_pwrite()/os_file_pread() code. Compare with how EINTR is handled in
my_pwrite()/my_pread().
bugs.bug_title: MySQL bug #60788: 	InnoDB crashes with an assertion failure when receiving a signal on pwrite()

bugs.bug_description:
We have a Rails App on Ubuntu Linux, that I am attempting to get working with the Percona 5.5. server. 

Our rails application  is attempting to use  libmysqlclient.so.16,  but this version of the library does not exist.

In /usr/lib, after installation:

$ ls -l libmysql*
-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 14915682 2011-04-27 21:20 libmysqlclient.a
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root       16 2011-05-04 16:19 libmysqlclient_r.a -> libmysqlclient.a
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root       22 2011-05-04 16:19 libmysqlclient_r.so -> libmysqlclient_r.so.16
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root       20 2011-05-04 16:19 libmysqlclient.so -> libmysqlclient.so.16
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root       24 2011-05-04 16:19 libmysqlclient.so.18 -> libmysqlclient.so.18.0.0
-rw-r--r-- 1 root root  6871762 2011-04-27 21:20 libmysqlclient.so.18.0.0
-rw-r--r-- 1 root root    10000 2011-04-27 21:20 libmysqlservices.a

In addition, we use Nagios for service monitoring. It fails to install because of a broken dependency:

nagios-plugins-standard: Depends: libmysqlclient16 (>= 5.1.21-1) but it is not going to be installed. I'm guessing that it wont install because of the (later) versioned percona packages?

Should there not be a working version of libmysqlclient16 shipped with the server?

Many Thanks
Steve



Version: 5.5_5.5.10-rc20.1-98 (also tried 5.5_5.5.11-rel20.2-115)
OS: Ubuntu 10.4 Lucid
Packages Installed: (listed using dpkg)

ii  percona-server-client-5.5             5.5.11-rel20.2-115.lucid              Percona Server database client binaries
ii  percona-server-common-5.5             5.5.11-rel20.2-115.lucid              Percona Server database common files (e.g. /etc/mysql/my.cnf)
ii  percona-server-server-5.5             5.5.11-rel20.2-115.lucid              Percona Server database server binaries

bugs.bug_description:
http://ec2-75-101-139-139.compute-1.amazonaws.com/job/percona-server-5.1-trunk/BUILD_TYPE=debug-no-Werror,Host=ubuntu-lucid-64bit/14/console
(all debug builds)

First occurs:
rpl.rpl_binlog_errors 'mix'              w1 [ pass ]  86537

MTR's internal check of the test case 'rpl.rpl_binlog_errors' failed.
This means that the test case does not preserve the state that existed
before the test case was executed.  Most likely the test case did not
do a proper clean-up. It could also be caused by the previous test run
by this thread, if the server wasn't restarted.
This is the diff of the states of the servers before and after the
test case was executed:
mysqltest: Logging to '/jenkins/workspace/percona-server-5.1-trunk/BUILD_TYPE/debug-no-Werror/Host/ubuntu-lucid-64bit/Percona-Server-5.1.57/mysql-test/var/1/tmp/check-mysqld_1.log'.
mysqltest: Results saved in '/jenkins/workspace/percona-server-5.1-trunk/BUILD_TYPE/debug-no-Werror/Host/ubuntu-lucid-64bit/Percona-Server-5.1.57/mysql-test/var/1/tmp/check-mysqld_1.result'.
mysqltest: Connecting to server localhost:13000 (socket /tmp/WCjGnx4Rbk/1/mysqld.1.sock) as 'root', connection 'default', attempt 0 ...
mysqltest: ... Connected.
mysqltest: Start processing test commands from './include/check-testcase.test' ...
mysqltest: ... Done processing test commands.
--- /jenkins/workspace/percona-server-5.1-trunk/BUILD_TYPE/debug-no-Werror/Host/ubuntu-lucid-64bit/Percona-Server-5.1.57/mysql-test/var/1/tmp/check-mysqld_1.result	2011-06-08 19:10:46.000000000 +0300
+++ /jenkins/workspace/percona-server-5.1-trunk/BUILD_TYPE/debug-no-Werror/Host/ubuntu-lucid-64bit/Percona-Server-5.1.57/mysql-test/var/1/tmp/check-mysqld_1.reject	2011-06-08 19:12:14.000000000 +0300
@@ -101,7 +101,7 @@
 INNODB_FAST_RECOVERY	OFF
 INNODB_FAST_SHUTDOWN	1

-INNODB_FILE_FORMAT_CHECK	Antelope
+INNODB_FILE_FORMAT_CHECK	Barracuda
 INNODB_FILE_PER_TABLE	OFF
 INNODB_FLUSH_LOG_AT_TRX_COMMIT	1
 INNODB_FLUSH_LOG_AT_TRX_COMMIT_SESSION	3

mysqltest: Result content mismatch

bugs.bug_description:
hi，i'm using Percona-Server 5.5.10(and 5.5.12)，i meet the bug like：InnoDB: error in sec index entry update(http://bugs.mysql.com/bug.php?id=37364)
there are 2 tables as:
CREATE TABLE `t1` (
`id` bigint(20) NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT,
`guid` bigint(20) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
`name` varchar(255) NOT NULL DEFAULT '',
`charguid` bigint(20) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
`charname` varchar(255) NOT NULL DEFAULT '',
`level` int(10) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
PRIMARY KEY (`id`),
KEY `idx_charguid` (`charguid`),
KEY `idx_guid` (`guid`)
) ENGINE=InnoDB;

CREATE TABLE `t2` (
`aid` bigint(20) NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT,
`guid` bigint(20) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
`name` varchar(255) NOT NULL DEFAULT '',
`level` int(10) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
`charguid` bigint(20) unsigned NOT NULL DEFAULT '0',
`charname` varchar(255) NOT NULL DEFAULT '',
PRIMARY KEY (`aid`),
KEY `idx_guid` (`guid`),
KEY `idx_charguid` (`charguid`)
) ENGINE=InnoDB;

and create a procedure as:
delimiter $$$
drop procedure testproc $$$
create procedure testproc()
begin
truncate table t1;
insert into t1(guid,charguid,level,charname,name) select guid,charguid,level,charname,name from t2;
update t1,t2 set t1.charguid=t2.charguid where t1.guid=t2.guid;
end $$$
delimiter ;

execute the procedure, it report the error message:
mysql> call testbug();
ERROR 1062 (23000): Duplicate entry '1' for key 'PRIMARY'

error log message print:
InnoDB: error in sec index entry update in
InnoDB: index `idx_charguid` of table `test`.`t1`
InnoDB: tuple DATA TUPLE: 2 fields;
0: len 8; hex 80e7fe000001bd12; asc         ;;
1: len 8; hex 80000000000051bf; asc       Q ;;
InnoDB: record PHYSICAL RECORD: n_fields 2; compact format; info bits 0
0: len 8; hex 80e7fe000001bd12; asc         ;;
1: len 8; hex 80000000000048bb; asc       H ;;
TRANSACTION 43A5C4, ACTIVE 0 sec, process no 22742, OS thread id 1351932224 updating or deleting, thread declared inside InnoDB 210
mysql tables in use 2, locked 2
300 lock struct(s), heap size 31160, 22902 row lock(s), undo log entries 7105
MySQL thread id 24962, query id 2206535128 localhost root updating reference tables
update t1,t2 set t1.charguid=t2.charguid where t1.guid=t2.guid;
InnoDB: Submit a detailed bug report to http://bugs.mysql.com

bugs.bug_description:
Server version: 5.5.12-55-log Percona Server (GPL), Release rel20.3, Revision 118

I found this blog post while searching for my bug:
http://www.mysqlperformanceblog.com/2011/06/02/active-with-locks-now-thats-a-problem/

This occurs on my server, but seems like a bug in Percona-server. An "ACTIVE" transaction holds locks for tens of seconds, causing other queries to wait for it. However, the client for that transaction thinks it is still waiting on the result of a query! It really looks like the thread is hung somewhere, as the query does not appear in SHOW FULL PROCESSLIST;

It doesn't always happen, but it is reproducible even on SELECT statements outside of a transaction by running a query for a random single row in a loop by primary key. Usually it takes 0.1ms, but sometimes it can take several seconds, or even tens or hundreds of seconds. Using SQL profiling, the query appears to have run very quickly, so I don't know where Percona is spending all the time. It doesn't seem to be tied to a particular table.

The machine does not appear to be swapping or maxed out on IO. Here's the vmstat 1 10 output during the problem:

procs -----------memory---------- ---swap-- -----io---- --system-- -----cpu------
 r  b   swpd   free   buff  cache   si   so    bi    bo   in   cs us sy id wa st
 0  2   9560  39404  45388 3939228    0    0   541   714    1    1 14  1 73 12  0
 1  2   9560  36356  45404 3941936    0    0  1592  6021 3773 3132 16  1 51 32  0
 1  3   9560  34160  45404 3943392    0    0  1716  3646 1739 1418  4  1 70 25  0
 0  2   9560  31924  45404 3945768    0    0  2064   607 1539 1382  3  0 67 30  0
 2  0   9560  33632  45376 3943976    0    0   404   411 1755 1271  9  1 85  5  0
 0  1   9560  43380  45336 3933828    0    0   632    86 2792 1989 11  1 74 15  0
 0  1   9560  43380  45336 3934920    0    0   644    93 2426 1720  7  1 80 13  0
 0  0   9560  42004  45344 3935344    0    0   452    77 2397 1607 10  1 76 13  0
 0  1   9560  42004  45344 3935708    0    0   500    17 1847 1449  3  0 87  9  0
 0  1   9560  40548  45344 3937056    0    0  1044    45 2032 1644  5  0 80 15  0


Let me know if there's anything else I can do to help debug this problem.

bugs.bug_description:
Percona-Server-5.5.13-rel20.4-136.Linux.x86_64.

Dumping a table with "mysqldump --innodb-optimize-keys" drops the keys and constraints from the create and adds the alter table to add them back, which is good. But the alter statement fails with:
ERROR 1005 (HY000) at line 2099: Can't create table 'db.#sql-6c1c_37' (errno: 121)

The table has 12 secondary indexes and 7 foreign key constraints. Also not sure this is supposed to work, but there are indications on http://www.percona.com/docs/wiki/percona-server:features:innodb_fast_index_creation, that it shall.
"Delaying foreign key creation does not introduce any additional risks, as mysqldump always prepends its output with SET FOREIGN_KEY_CHECKS=0 anyway."
bugs.bug_title: mysqldump --innodb-optimize-keys, can't create table
bugs.title: Bug #805944 in Percona Server: "mysqldump --innodb-optimize-keys, can't create table"

bugs.bug_description:
For some reasons fdatasync() is available but is not declared on OS X. So after the patch for bug #803270 I get the following warning (actually error, since I build with -Werror):

os/os0file.c: In function ‘os_file_fsync’:
os/os0file.c:1967: warning: implicit declaration of function ‘fdatasync’.

The solution is to replace

#ifdef HAVE_FDATASYNC

with

#if defined(HAVE_FDATASYNC) && HAVE_DECL_FDATASYNC

That's what the server has in my_sync.c
bugs.bug_title: patch for bug #803270 breaks OS X

bugs.bug_description:
We recently setup two new servers running CentOS 5.6 x86_64 with Percona Server 5.5.12-55-log installed from the Percona yum repo. The servers are receiving statement based replication from our production environment.  Both servers' mysqld crash at the same time however production environment remained stable. 

The first server dumped this to the mysql.log:

110712 12:40:32 - mysqld got signal 11 ;
This could be because you hit a bug. It is also possible that this binary
or one of the libraries it was linked against is corrupt, improperly built,
or misconfigured. This error can also be caused by malfunctioning hardware.
We will try our best to scrape up some info that will hopefully help diagnose
the problem, but since we have already crashed, something is definitely wrong
and this may fail.

key_buffer_size=2097152000
read_buffer_size=2097152
max_used_connections=3
max_threads=1000
thread_count=0
connection_count=0
It is possible that mysqld could use up to 
key_buffer_size + (read_buffer_size + sort_buffer_size)*max_threads = 6155898 K
bytes of memory
Hope that's ok; if not, decrease some variables in the equation.

bugs.bug_description:
The mysqldump option --innodb-optimize-keys does not work correctly with tables where the first UNIQUE key on non-nullable columns was picked as the clustered index by InnoDB in the absence of a PRIMARY KEY.

Example:

mysql> CREATE TABLE t1 (a INT NOT NULL, UNIQUE KEY (a)) ENGINE=InnoDB;
Query OK, 0 rows affected (0.02 sec)

mysql> SHOW COLUMNS FROM t1;
+-------+---------+------+-----+---------+-------+
| Field | Type    | Null | Key | Default | Extra |
+-------+---------+------+-----+---------+-------+
| a     | int(11) | NO   | PRI | NULL    |       |
+-------+---------+------+-----+---------+-------+
1 row in set (0.00 sec)

Output of mysqldump --innodb-optimize-keys:

CREATE TABLE `t1` (
  `a` int(11) NOT NULL 
) ENGINE=InnoDB DEFAULT CHARSET=latin1;
...
ALTER TABLE `t1` ADD UNIQUE KEY `a` (`a`);

The optimization should detect such tables and keep the unique key in CREATE TABLE.
bugs.bug_title: --innodb-optimize-keys does not work correctly with table without PRIMARY KEY
bugs.title: Bug #851674 in Percona Server: "--innodb-optimize-keys does not work correctly with table without PRIMARY KEY"

bugs.bug_description:
Reported upstream as http://bugs.mysql.com/bug.php?id=62516

After adding an index using fast index creation, statistics for that index provided by
InnoDB is left in a bogus state until an explicit ANALYZE TABLE is executed. This is not
the case for the old method of adding indexes by copying rows used by builtin InnoDB.

How to repeat:
drop table if exists t1;
create table t1(id int not null auto_increment primary key, a char(1) not null, b
char(36) not null) engine=innodb;
insert into t1(a,b) values ('a','b');
insert into t1(a,b) select a,b from t1;
insert into t1(a,b) select a,b from t1;
insert into t1(a,b) select a,b from t1;
insert into t1(a,b) select a,b from t1;
alter table t1 add key (a);

Builtin InnoDB in 5.1:

mysql> explain select count(*) from t1, t1 t2 where t1.a = t2.a and t1.b = t2.b\G
*************************** 1. row ***************************
           id: 1
  select_type: SIMPLE
        table: t1
         type: ALL
possible_keys: NULL
          key: NULL
      key_len: NULL
          ref: NULL
         rows: 16
        Extra: 
*************************** 2. row ***************************
           id: 1
  select_type: SIMPLE
        table: t2
         type: ALL
possible_keys: NULL
          key: NULL
      key_len: NULL
          ref: NULL
         rows: 16
        Extra: Using where; Using join buffer
2 rows in set (0.01 sec)

InnoDB plugin 1.0.17:

mysql> explain select count(*) from t1, t1 t2 where t1.a = t2.a and t1.b = t2.b\G
*************************** 1. row ***************************
           id: 1
  select_type: SIMPLE
        table: t1
         type: ALL
possible_keys: a
          key: NULL
      key_len: NULL
          ref: NULL
         rows: 16
        Extra: 
*************************** 2. row ***************************
           id: 1
  select_type: SIMPLE
        table: t2
         type: ref
possible_keys: a
          key: a
      key_len: 1
          ref: test.t1.a
         rows: 1
        Extra: Using where
2 rows in set (0.00 sec)

mysql> analyze table t1;
+---------+---------+----------+----------+
| Table   | Op      | Msg_type | Msg_text |
+---------+---------+----------+----------+
| test.t1 | analyze | status   | OK       |
+---------+---------+----------+----------+
1 row in set (0.00 sec)

mysql> explain select count(*) from t1, t1 t2 where t1.a = t2.a and t1.b = t2.b\G
*************************** 1. row ***************************
           id: 1
  select_type: SIMPLE
        table: t1
         type: ALL
possible_keys: a
          key: NULL
      key_len: NULL
          ref: NULL
         rows: 16
        Extra: 
*************************** 2. row ***************************
           id: 1
  select_type: SIMPLE
        table: t2
         type: ALL
possible_keys: a
          key: NULL
      key_len: NULL
          ref: NULL
         rows: 16
        Extra: Using where; Using join buffer
2 rows in set (0.01 sec)

Suggested fix:
Update statistics after fast index creation.

bugs.bug_description:
Discovered when trying to modify innodb_lru_dump_restore.patch. The build failed with:

dict/dict0dict.c: In function ‘dict_reload_statistics’:
dict/dict0dict.c:4308: error: ‘dict_table_t’ has no member named ‘is_corrupt’
dict/dict0dict.c:4309: error: ‘srv_pass_corrupt_table’ undeclared (first use in this function)
dict/dict0dict.c:4309: error: (Each undeclared identifier is reported only once
dict/dict0dict.c:4309: error: for each function it appears in.)
dict/dict0dict.c: In function ‘dict_store_statistics’:
dict/dict0dict.c:4461: error: ‘dict_table_t’ has no member named ‘is_corrupt’
dict/dict0dict.c:4462: error: ‘srv_pass_corrupt_table’ undeclared (first use in this function)

'is_corrupt' and ‘srv_pass_corrupt_table’ are declared in innodb_pass_corrupt_table.patch, but are used in innodb_stats.patch which is 8 patches behind innodb_pass_corrupt_table.patch in series. So essentially all of the following patches cannot be built (and thus, worked on) independently:

innodb_stats.patch
innodb_recovery_patches.patch
innodb_purge_thread.patch
innodb_admin_command_base.patch
innodb_show_lock_name.patch
innodb_extend_slow.patch
innodb_lru_dump_restore.patch
innodb_separate_doublewrite.patch

The solution is probably to move innodb_stats.patch after innodb_pass_corrupt_table.patch, then fix a number of conflicts due to different context lines, then regenerate file offsets and hope no other patches get broken due to other dependencies.
bugs.bug_title: Broken builds for some patches due to dependencies and wrong order in series
bugs.title: Bug #858467 in Percona Server: "Broken builds for some patches due to dependencies and wrong order in series"

bugs.bug_description:
The server-side functionality from innodb_expand_fast_index_creation.patch should be made optional for a number of reasons:

1. We promise the same behavior as compared to the upstream server unless Percona-specific features are explicitly enabled by corresponding options.

2. Fast index creation may actually be slower than the default method in some cases.  (e.g. when the data fits in the buffer pool and the merge buffer is too small, see https://blueprints.launchpad.net/percona-server/+spec/tunable-buffer-size-for-merge-sort)

3. There are upstream server bugs that make fast index creation inefficient in even more cases, for example https://bugs.launchpad.net/bugs/810571

We should have an option controlling whether fast index creation is used, and it should be disabled by default.
bugs.bug_title: innodb_expand_fast_index_creation should be optional
bugs.title: Bug #858945 in Percona Server: "innodb_expand_fast_index_creation should be optional"

bugs.bug_description:
InnoDB requires a full table rebuild for foreign key changes. So it doesn't make sense to delay their creation by moving them from CREATE TABLE to a separate ALTER TABLE in a mysqldump output.

So --innodb-optimize-keys should ignore foreign key constrains. Documentation for innodb_expand_fast_index_creation.patch should be changed to reflect that.
bugs.bug_title: --innodb-optimize-keys should ignore foreign keys
bugs.title: Bug #859078 in Percona Server: "--innodb-optimize-keys should ignore foreign keys"
